# Motivation

To practice R programming through hands-on exercises, as it is the best way to enhance your programming skills.

# 1.2.5 Exercises

This tutorial demonstrates fundamental plotting using the ggplot2 package. The exercises presented here are sourced from Chapter 1 of the famous **R 4 Data Science by Hadley Wickham et al.** Let's get started!

# Loading Required Libraries

In this section, we will load `tidyverse`, `ggtext`, `palmerpenguins`, and ` ggthemes`packages.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(ggtext)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(ggthemes)
```
:::




## Plot Body Mass (g) vs. Flipper Length (mm)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Initialize a canvas.
ggplot(
  penguins,
  aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)
) +
  # Add points
  geom_point(
    aes(color = species, shape = species),
    na.rm = TRUE
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm",
    na.rm = TRUE,
    formula = "y ~ x"
  ) +
  scale_color_colorblind() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(2000, 6000),
    breaks = seq(2000, 6000, 1000),
    labels = scales::label_number(scale = 1e-3, suffix = "K")
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Body mass and flipper length",
    subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins",
    x = "Flipper length (mm)",
    y = "Body mass (g)",
    color = "Species",
    shape = "Species"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_textbox_simple(hjust = 0),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(hjust = 0, margin = margin(b = 15)),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Body mass and flipper length. There exists a positive linear relationship between Body mass (g) and flipper length (mm).](tutorial-03_files/figure-html/fig-penguins-1-1.png){#fig-penguins-1 width=672}
:::
:::


## Make a Scatterplot of Bill Depth (mm) vs. Bill Length (mm)

Make a scatterplot of `bill_depth_mm` vs.`bill_length_mm`. That is, make a scatterplot with `bill_depth_mm` on the y-axis and `bill_length_mm` on the x-axis. Describe the relationship between these two variables.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Initialize a canvas.
g <-
  ggplot(
    penguins,
    aes(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm)
  ) +
  # Add points
  geom_point(
    aes(color = species, shape = species),
    na.rm = TRUE
  ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm",
    na.rm = TRUE,
    formula = "y ~ x"
  ) +
  scale_color_colorblind() +
  labs(
    title = "Bill Legnth and Bill Depth",
    subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins",
    x = "Bill length (mm)",
    y = "Bill Depth (mm)",
    color = "Species",
    shape = "Species"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_textbox_simple(hjust = 0),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox(hjust = 0, margin = margin(b = 15)),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

g
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![Bill Legnth and Bill Depth. There is a negative linear relationship between Bill Length (mm) and Bill Depth (mm).](tutorial-03_files/figure-html/fig-penguins-2-1.png){#fig-penguins-2 width=672}
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}

		expand = c(0.02, 0.02),
		limits = c(0, 200)
	) +
	labs(
		title = "Plot of Penguin Species in Descending Order",
		y = "Species",
		x = "Frequency"
	)
```

Why does the following yield two separate legends? How would you fix it to combine the two legends?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(
  penguins,
  aes(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm,
    color = species, shape = species
  )
) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(color = "Species")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
```
:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](tutorial-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Resolving double legends
ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm)) +
  geom_point(
    aes(color = species, shape = species),
    na.rm = TRUE,
    show.legend = TRUE
  ) +
  labs(
    color = "Species",
    shape = "Species"
  )
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](tutorial-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-2.png){width=672}
:::
:::


# Conclusion

In this tutorial, we walked you through the steps for answering section 25.3.5 exercises from R for Data Science, 2nd edition by Wickham et al., demonstrating, where possible, different approaches for answering these questions.
Our work highlighted some ways to solve these exercises; however, there are many ways one could solve them.
Please try them and share your answers with us and our readers.
